title: Calculation method
text: basic method estimating gene expression conditions relies calculating fold differences using PCR amplification efficiency (EE) threshold cycle (also called crossing point, CtC_t). Among various approaches analyzing real-time PCR data, Livak method—also known 2−ΔΔCt2^{-\Delta\Delta C_t} method—widely used simplicity reliability. method, fold change (FC) expression, 2−ΔΔCt2^{-\Delta\Delta C_t}, Treatment (Tr) group relative Control (Co) group calculated follows: Fold change=2−ΔΔCt=2−(Ct,target−Ct,ref)Tr2−(Ct,target−Ct,ref)Co=2−[(Ct,target−Ct,ref)Tr−(Ct,target−Ct,ref)Co]=2−[(ΔCt)Tr−(ΔCt)Co]   \begin{align*} \text{Fold change} &= 2^{-\Delta\Delta C_t} \\ &= \frac{2^{-(C_{t,\text{target}} - C_{t,\text{ref}})_{\text{Tr}}}} {2^{-(C_{t,\text{target}} - C_{t,\text{ref}})_{\text{Co}}}} \\ &= 2^{-[(C_{t,\text{target}} - C_{t,\text{ref}})_{\text{Tr}}         - (C_{t,\text{target}} - C_{t,\text{ref}})_{\text{Co}}]} \\ &= 2^{-[(\Delta C_t)_{\text{Tr}} - (\Delta C_t)_{\text{Co}}]} \end{align*} , ΔCt\Delta C_t difference target Ct reference Ct values given sample. Livak method assumes target reference genes amplified efficiencies close 100%, allowing relative quantification gene expression levels. hand, Pfaffl method offers flexible approach accounting differences amplification efficiencies target reference genes. method adjusts calculated expression ratio incorporating specific amplification efficiencies, thus providing accurate representation relative gene expression levels. Fold change=Etarget−(Ct,Tr−Ct,Co)Eref−(Ct,Tr−Ct,Co)   \text{Fold change} =   \frac{E_{\text{target}}^{-(C_{t,\text{Tr}} - C_{t,\text{Co}})}} {E_{\text{ref}}^{-(C_{t,\text{Tr}} - C_{t,\text{Co}})}}

title: Calculation method
text: rtpcr package developed R environment major operating systems. package functions mainly based calculation efficiency-weighted ΔCt\Delta C_t(wΔCt)(w\Delta C_t) values target reference gene Ct (equation 3). wΔCtw\Delta C_t values weighted amplification efficiencies described Ganger et al. (2017) except log2 used instead log10: wΔCt=log2(Etarget)⋅Ct,target−log2(Eref)⋅Ct,ref   w\Delta C_t =   \log_2(E_{\text{target}}) \cdot C_{t,\text{target}} -   \log_2(E_{\text{ref}}) \cdot C_{t,\text{ref}}  one reference gene, log2E.Ct term references, whole wDCt defined using geometric mean follow: wCt=log2(Etarget)⋅Cttarget−(∏=1n[log2(geoMeanE)⋅Ctrefi])1/n wCt = \log_{2}\!\left(E_{\text{target}}\right)\cdot Ct_{\text{target}} - \left( \prod_{=1}^{n} \left[ \log_{2}\!\left(\text{geoMeanE}\right)\cdot Ct_{\text{ref}_i} \right] \right)^{1/n}  geometric mean efficieny values referene genes : geoMeanE=(∏=1nErefi)1/n \text{geoMeanE} = \left( \prod_{=1}^{n} E_{\text{ref}_i} \right)^{1/n} relative expression target gene normalized reference gene(s) within sample condition called relative expression (RE). mean wΔCtw\Delta C_t values biological replicates, RE target gene can calculated condition according equation Relative Expression=2−wΔCt¯   \text{Relative Expression} = 2^{-\overline{w\Delta C_t}} Relative expression calibrated reference gene(s) control condition. However, often one condition considered calibrator fold change (FC) expression conditions calculated relative calibrator. Examples Treatment versus Control Control served calibrator, time 0 versus time 1 (e.g. 1 hour) time 2 (e.g. 2 hours) time 0 served reference calibrator level. , calibrator reference level sample others compared . fold change (FC) expression target gene reference calibrator level 1 changed compared . fold change expression target gene due treatment can calculated follows: Fold Change due Treatment=2−(wΔCt¯Tr−wΔCt¯Co)   \text{Fold Change due Treatment} =   2^{-(\overline{w\Delta C_t}_{\text{Tr}} - \overline{w\Delta C_t}_{\text{Co}})} Standard error FC RE means calculated according Taylor et al. (2019) rtpcr package. , brief methodology presented details wΔCtw\Delta C_t calculations statistical analysis available Ganger et al. (2017). Importantly, relative expression values follow lognormal distribution, normal distribution expected wΔCtw \Delta C_t values making possible apply t-test analysis variance. Following analysis, wΔCtw\Delta C_t values statistically compared standard deviations confidence interval calculated, transformation y=2−xy = 2^{-x} applied final step order report results.

title: rtpcr package help
text: Tools analysis RT-qPCR gene expression data using ΔCt ΔΔCt methods, including t-tests, ANOVA, ANCOVA, repeated-measures models, publication-ready visualizations. package implements general calculation method described Ganger et al. (2017) Taylor et al. (2019), covering Livak Pfaffl methods. See calculation method details.

text: rtpcr package gets efficiency (E) Ct values genes performs different analyses using following functions.

code: # Installing from CRAN install.packages("rtpcr")  # Loading the package library(rtpcr) devtools::install_github("mirzaghaderi/rtpcr", build_vignettes = FALSE)

title: rtpcr package help
text: relative expression analysis (using TTEST_DDCt, ANOVA_DCt, ANOVA_DDCt REPEATED_DDCt functions), amplification efficiency (E) Ct Cq values (mean technical replicates) used input table. E values available use ‘2’ instead representing complete primer amplification efficiency. required column structure input data : Experimental condition columns (3 factors, one block available) Replicates information (biological replicates subjects; see NOTE 1, NOTE 2) Target genes efficiency Ct values (pair column gene). Reference genes efficiency Ct values (pair column gene) package supports one target reference gene(s), supplied efficiency–Ct column pairs. Reference gene columns must always appear last. sample input data presented .

title: rtpcr package help
text: TTEST_DDCt, ANOVA_DCt, ANOVA_DDCt, row separate uniq biological replicate. example, dataframe 12 rows come experiment 12 individuals. REPEATED_DDCt function intended experiments repeated observations (e.g. time-course data). REPEATED_DDCt, Replicate column contains identifiers individual (id subject). example, rows 1 Rep column correspond single individual, rows 2 correspond another individual, , sampled specific time points.

title: rtpcr package help
text: data table may also include technical replicates. case, meanTech function applied first calculate mean technical replicates. resulting table used input expression analysis. use meanTech function correctly, technical replicate column must appear immediately biological replicate column (see Mean technical replicates example).

title: rtpcr package help
text: efficiency function calculates amplification efficiency (E), slope, R² statistics genes, performs pairwise comparisons slopes. takes data frame first column contains dilution ratios, followed Ct value columns gene.

title: rtpcr package help
text: Relative expression analysis can done using ΔΔCt ΔCt methods. example expression analysis using ΔΔCt method.
code: # An example of a properly arranged dataset from a repeated-measures experiment. data <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_repeated_measure_1.csv", package = "rtpcr")) data  time    id  E_Target    Ct_target   E_Ref      Ct_Ref    1     1      2       18.92   2   32.77    1     2      2       15.82   2   32.45    1     3      2       19.84   2   31.62    2     1      2       19.46   2   33.03    2     2      2       17.56   2   33.24    2     3      2       19.74   2   32.08    3     1      2       15.73   2   32.95    3     2      2       17.21   2   33.64    3     3      2       18.09   2   33.40  # Repeated measure analysis res <- REPEATED_DDCt(   data,   numOfFactors = 1,   numberOfrefGenes = 1,   repeatedFactor = "time",   calibratorLevel = "1",   block = NULL)   # Anova analysis ANOVA_DDCt(   data,   mainFactor.column = 1,   numOfFactors = 1,   numberOfrefGenes = 1,   block = NULL)   # Paired t.test (equivalent to repeated measure analysis, but not always the same results, due to different calculation methods!) TTEST_DDCt(   data[1:6,],    numberOfrefGenes = 1,    paired = T)   # Anova analysis data <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_2factorBlock3ref.csv", package = "rtpcr")) res <- ANOVA_DDCt(   x = data,   mainFactor.column = 1,   numOfFactors = 2,   numberOfrefGenes = 1,   block = "block",   analyseAllTarget = TRUE)

code: data <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_3factor.csv", package = "rtpcr")) #Perform analysis first res <- ANOVA_DCt(   data,   numOfFactors = 3,   numberOfrefGenes = 1,   block = NULL)    df <- res$combinedResults  df  # Generate three-factor bar plot  p <- plotFactor(   df,   x_col = "SA",          y_col = "log2FC",          group_col = "Type",      facet_col = "Conc",       Lower.se_col = "Lower.se.log2FC",   Upper.se_col = "Upper.se.log2FC",   letters_col = "sig",   letters_d = 0.3,   col_width = 0.7,    dodge_width = 0.7,   fill_colors = c("palegreen3", "skyblue"),   color = "black",   base_size = 14,    alpha = 1,   legend_position = c(0.1, 0.2))  library(ggplot2) p + theme(   panel.border = element_rect(color = "black", linewidth = 0.5))

title: rtpcr package help
code: data <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_2factorBlock.csv", package = "rtpcr")) res <- ANOVA_DCt(data,        numOfFactors = 2,       block = "block",       numberOfrefGenes = 1)  df <- res$combinedResults  p1 <- plotFactor(   data = df,   x_col = "factor2",   y_col = "RE",   group_col = "factor1",   Lower.se_col = "Lower.se.RE",   Upper.se_col = "Upper.se.RE",   letters_col = "sig",   letters_d = 0.2,   fill_colors = c("aquamarine4", "gold2"),   color = "black",   alpha = 1,   col_width = 0.7,   dodge_width = 0.7,   base_size = 16,    legend_position = c(0.2, 0.8))  library(ggplot2) p1 +    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(size = 14, color = "black", angle = 45),         axis.text.y = element_text(size = 14,color = "black", angle = 0, hjust = 0.5)) +   theme(legend.text = element_text(colour = "black", size = 14),         legend.background = element_rect(fill = "transparent")) +   scale_y_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1)))

title: rtpcr package help
code: # Heffer et al., 2020, PlosOne library(dplyr) df <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "Heffer2020PlosOne.csv", package = "rtpcr"))  res <- ANOVA_DDCt(   df,   numOfFactors = 1,   mainFactor.column = 1,   numberOfrefGenes = 1,   block = NULL)  data <- res$combinedFoldChange data$gene <- factor(data$gene, levels = unique(data$gene))  # Selecting only the first words in 'contrast' column to be used as the x-axis labels. data$contrast <- sub(" .*", "", data$contrast)  # Converting the 'contrast' column as factor and fix the current level order data$contrast <- factor(data$contrast, levels = unique(data$contrast))  p <- plotFactor(   data = data,   x_col = "contrast",   y_col = "RE",   group_col = "contrast",   facet_col = "gene",   Lower.se_col = "Lower.se.RE",   Upper.se_col = "Upper.se.RE",   letters_col = "sig",   letters_d = 0.2,   alpha = 1,   fill_colors = palette.colors(4, recycle = TRUE),   color = "black",   col_width = 0.5,   dodge_width = 0.5,   base_size = 16,    legend_position = "none")  library(ggplot2) p + theme(   panel.border = element_rect(color = "black", linewidth = 0.5)) +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(size = 14, color = "black", angle = 45, hjust = 1)) +   xlab(NULL) +   scale_y_continuous(expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1))) +   theme(     strip.background = element_blank(),  # removes the faceting gray background     strip.text = element_text(face = "bold")) # optional: keeps the text visible

title: rtpcr package help
text: Means_DDCt function performs post-hoc comparisons using fitted model object produced ANOVA_DCt, ANOVA_DDCt REPEATED_DDCt. applies pairwise statistical comparisons relative expression (RE) values user-specified effects via specs argument. Supported effects include simple effects, interactions, slicing, provided underlying model ANOVA. ANCOVA models returned package, Means_DDCt output limited simple effects .
code: res <- ANOVA_DDCt(   data_3factor,   numOfFactors = 3,   numberOfrefGenes = 1,   mainFactor.column = 1,   block = NULL)   # Relative expression values for Concentration main effect Means_DDCt(res$perGene$E_PO$lm_ANOVA, specs = "Conc")   contrast        RE        SE df       LCL       UCL p.value sig  L vs H   0.1703610 0.2208988 24 0.1242014 0.2336757 <0.0001 ***  M vs H   0.2227247 0.2208988 24 0.1623772 0.3055004 <0.0001 ***  M vs L   1.3073692 0.2208988 24 0.9531359 1.7932535  0.0928 .    Results are averaged over the levels of: Type, SA  Confidence level used: 0.95   # Relative expression values for Concentration sliced by Type Means_DDCt(res$perGene$E_PO$lm_ANOVA, specs = "Conc | Type")  Type = R:  contrast       RE        SE df       LCL      UCL p.value sig  L vs H   0.103187 0.3123981 24 0.0659984 0.161331 <0.0001 ***  M vs H   0.339151 0.3123981 24 0.2169210 0.530255 <0.0001 ***  M vs L   3.286761 0.3123981 24 2.1022126 5.138776 <0.0001 ***  Type = S:  contrast       RE        SE df       LCL      UCL p.value sig  L vs H   0.281265 0.3123981 24 0.1798969 0.439751 <0.0001 ***  M vs H   0.146266 0.3123981 24 0.0935518 0.228684 <0.0001 ***  M vs L   0.520030 0.3123981 24 0.3326112 0.813055  0.0059 **   Results are averaged over the levels of: SA  Confidence level used: 0.95   # Relative expression values for Concentration sliced by Type and SA Means_DDCt(res$perGene$E_PO$lm_ANOVA, specs = "Conc | Type * SA")

title: rtpcr package help
text: residuals t.test lm lmer object normally distributed, significance results might violated. cases, non-parametric tests can used. example, Mann–Whitney test (also known Wilcoxon rank-sum test), implemented via wilcox.test(), alternative t.test, kruskal.test() alternative one-way analysis variance. tests assess differences population medians using independent samples. However, t.test function (along TTEST_DDCt function described ) includes var.equal argument. set FALSE, perform t.test unequal variances hypothesis. Residuals lm (ANOVA_DCt ANOVA_DDCt functions) lmer (REPEATED_DDCt function) objects can extracted plotted follow:
code: data <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_repeated_measure_1.csv", package = "rtpcr")) res3 <- REPEATED_DDCt(   data,   numOfFactors = 1,   numberOfrefGenes = 1,   repeatedFactor = "time",   calibratorLevel = "1",   block = NULL ) residuals <- resid(res3$perGene$Target$lm) shapiro.test(residuals)  par(mfrow = c(1,2)) plot(residuals) qqnorm(residuals) qqline(residuals, col = "red")

title: rtpcr package help

code: # See example input data frame: data <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_withTechRep.csv", package = "rtpcr")) data  # Calculating mean of technical replicates meanTech(data, groups = 1:4)

text: Means_DDCt function performs post-hoc comparisons using fitted model object produced ANOVA_DCt, ANOVA_DDCt REPEATED_DDCt. applies pairwise statistical comparisons relative expression (RE) values user-specified effects via specs argument. Supported effects include simple effects, interactions, slicing, provided underlying model ANOVA. ANCOVA models returned package, Means_DDCt output limited simple effects .
code: res <- ANOVA_DDCt(   data_3factor,   numOfFactors = 3,   numberOfrefGenes = 1,   mainFactor.column = 1,   block = NULL)   # Relative expression values for Concentration main effect Means_DDCt(res$perGene$E_PO$lm_ANOVA, specs = "Conc")   # contrast        RE        SE df       LCL       UCL p.value sig  # L vs H   0.1703610 0.2208988 24 0.1242014 0.2336757 <0.0001 ***  # M vs H   0.2227247 0.2208988 24 0.1623772 0.3055004 <0.0001 ***  # M vs L   1.3073692 0.2208988 24 0.9531359 1.7932535  0.0928 .    Results are averaged over the levels of: Type, SA  Confidence level used: 0.95   # Relative expression values for Concentration sliced by Type Means_DDCt(res$perGene$E_PO$lm_ANOVA, specs = "Conc | Type")  # Type = R: #  contrast       RE        SE df       LCL      UCL p.value sig #  L vs H   0.103187 0.3123981 24 0.0659984 0.161331 <0.0001 *** #  M vs H   0.339151 0.3123981 24 0.2169210 0.530255 <0.0001 *** #  M vs L   3.286761 0.3123981 24 2.1022126 5.138776 <0.0001 ***  # Type = S: #  contrast       RE        SE df       LCL      UCL p.value sig #  L vs H   0.281265 0.3123981 24 0.1798969 0.439751 <0.0001 *** #  M vs H   0.146266 0.3123981 24 0.0935518 0.228684 <0.0001 *** #  M vs L   0.520030 0.3123981 24 0.3326112 0.813055  0.0059 **   # Results are averaged over the levels of: SA  # Confidence level used: 0.95   # Relative expression values for Concentration sliced by Type and SA Means_DDCt(res$perGene$E_PO$lm_ANOVA, specs = "Conc | Type * SA")

title: qPCR Data Analysis
text: residuals t.test lm lmer object normally distributed, significance results might violated. cases, non-parametric tests can used. example, Mann–Whitney test (also known Wilcoxon rank-sum test), implemented via wilcox.test(), alternative t.test, kruskal.test() alternative one-way analysis variance. tests assess differences population medians using independent samples. However, t.test function (along TTEST_DDCt function described ) includes var.equal argument. set FALSE, perform t.test unequal variances hypothesis. Residuals lm (ANOVA_DCt ANOVA_DDCt functions) lmer (REPEATED_DDCt function) objects can extracted plotted follow:
code: data <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_repeated_measure_1.csv", package = "rtpcr")) res3 <- REPEATED_DDCt(   data,   numOfFactors = 1,   numberOfrefGenes = 1,   repeatedFactor = "time",   calibratorLevel = "1",   block = NULL ) residuals <- resid(res3$perGene$Target$lm) shapiro.test(residuals)  par(mfrow = c(1,2)) plot(residuals) qqnorm(residuals) qqline(residuals, col = "red")

title: qPCR Data Analysis
text: Calculating mean technical replicates generating output table suitable subsequent ANOVA analysis can accomplished using meanTech function. input dataset must follow column structure illustrated example data . Columns used grouping explicitly specified via groups argument meanTech function.
code: # See example input data frame: data <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_withTechRep.csv", package = "rtpcr")) data  # Calculating mean of technical replicates meanTech(data, groups = 1:4)

title: ΔCt ANOVA analysis — ANOVA_DCt
text: x data frame containing experimental design columns, target gene E/Ct column pairs, reference gene E/Ct column pairs. Reference gene columns must located end data frame. numOfFactors Integer. Number experimental factor columns (excluding rep optional block). numberOfrefGenes Integer. Number reference genes. reference gene must represented two columns (E Ct). block Character NULL. Name blocking factor column. alpha statistical level comparisons adjust Method p-value adjustment. See p.adjust. analyseAllTarget Logical character. TRUE (default), detected target genes analysed. Alternatively, character vector specifying names (names Efficiency columns) target genes analysed.

title: ΔΔCt ANOVA analysis — ANOVA_DDCt
text: x data frame containing experimental design columns, target gene E/Ct column pairs, reference gene E/Ct column pairs. Reference gene columns must located end data frame. numOfFactors Integer. Number experimental factor columns (excluding rep optional block). numberOfrefGenes Integer. Number reference genes. reference gene must represented two columns (E Ct). mainFactor.column Column index name factor relative expression calculated. analysisType = "ancova", remaining factors treated covariates. analysisType Character string specifying analysis type; one "anova" (default) "ancova". mainFactor.level.order Optional character vector specifying order levels main factor. NULL, first observed level used calibrator. provided, first element vector used calibrator level. block Character NULL. Name blocking factor column. p.adj Method p-value adjustment. See p.adjust. plot Logical; FALSE, per gene-plots generated. plotType Plot scale use: "RE" relative expression "log2FC" log2 fold change. analyseAllTarget Logical character. TRUE (default), target genes analysed. Alternatively, character vector specifying names (names Efficiency columns) target genes analysed.

title: ΔΔCt ANOVA analysis — ANOVA_DDCt
text: ΔΔCt analysis performed mainFactor.column based full model factorial experiment default. However, ancova, analysisType argument, analysis covariance performed levels mainFactor.column factors treated covariates. interaction main factor covariate significant, ANCOVA appropriate. ANCOVA basically used factor affected uncontrolled quantitative covariate(s). example, suppose wDCt target gene plant affected temperature. gene may also affected drought. Since already know temperature affects target gene, interested know gene expression also altered drought levels. can design experiment understand gene behavior temperature drought levels time. drought another factor (covariate) may affect expression gene levels first factor .e. temperature. data experiment can analyzed ANCOVA using ANOVA based factorial experiment. ANCOVA done even one factor (without covariate factor  variable).

code: # Example using output from TTEST_DDCt data1 <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_1factor_one_ref.csv", package = "rtpcr")) a <- TTEST_DDCt(   data1,   numberOfrefGenes = 1,   plotType = "log2FC") #> *** 3 target(s) using 1 reference gene(s) was analysed! #> *** The control level was used as calibrator. p1 <- a$plot  # Example using output from ANOVA_DCt data2 <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_1factor.csv", package = "rtpcr")) out2 <- ANOVA_DCt(   data2,   numOfFactors = 1,   numberOfrefGenes = 1,   block = NULL) #> NULL #>  #> Relative expression (DCt method) #>   SA     RE  log2FC    LCL    UCL     se Lower.se.RE Upper.se.RE #> 1 L3 0.9885 -0.0167 1.5318 0.6379 0.0841      0.9325      1.0479 #> 2 L2 0.6271 -0.6733 0.9717 0.4047 0.4388      0.4626      0.8500 #> 3 L1 0.2852 -1.8100 0.4419 0.1840 0.0208      0.2811      0.2893 #>   Lower.se.log2FC Upper.se.log2FC sig #> 1         -0.0177         -0.0157   a #> 2         -0.9127         -0.4968   a #> 3         -1.8363         -1.7841   b #>  #> Combined Expression Table (all genes) #>   gene SA     RE  log2FC    LCL    UCL     se Lower.se.RE Upper.se.RE #> 1   PO L3 0.9885 -0.0167 1.5318 0.6379 0.0841      0.9325      1.0479 #> 2   PO L2 0.6271 -0.6733 0.9717 0.4047 0.4388      0.4626      0.8500 #> 3   PO L1 0.2852 -1.8100 0.4419 0.1840 0.0208      0.2811      0.2893 #>   Lower.se.log2FC Upper.se.log2FC sig #> 1         -0.0177         -0.0157   a #> 2         -0.9127         -0.4968   a #> 3         -1.8363         -1.7841   b    df <- out2$combinedResults  p2 <- plotFactor(   df,   x_col = "SA",   y_col = "RE",   Lower.se_col = "Lower.se.RE",   Upper.se_col = "Upper.se.RE",   letters_col = "sig",   letters_d = 0.1,   col_width = 0.7,   err_width = 0.15,   fill_colors = "skyblue",   alpha = 1,   base_size = 16)  # Combine plots into a single layout multiplot(p1, p2, cols = 2)   multiplot(p1, p2, cols = 1)

title: ΔΔCt ANOVA analysis on repeated measure data — REPEATED_DDCt
text: x input data frame first column id, followed factor column(s) include least time. first level time data frame used calibrator reference level. Additional factor(s) may also present. columns efficiency Ct values target reference genes. id column, unique number assigned individual samples taken time, example see data_repeated_measure_1, three number 1 indicate one individual sampled three different time courses. See example data sets refer vignettes, section "Input data structure" details. numOfFactors Integer. Number experimental factor columns (excluding optional block). numberOfrefGenes Integer. Number reference genes. reference gene must represented two columns (E Ct). repeatedFactor Character string specifying factor fold changes analysed (commonly "time"). calibratorLevel level repeatedFactor used calibrator (reference level) reference level sample others compared . Examples untreated time 0. block Optional blocking factor column name. supplied, block effects treated random effects. p.adj Method p-value adjustment. See p.adjust. plot Logical; FALSE, plots produced. analyseAllTarget Logical character. TRUE (default), detected target genes analysed. Alternatively, character vector specifying names (names Efficiency columns) target genes analysed.

title: ΔΔCt method t-test analysis — TTEST_DDCt
text: TTEST_DDCt function performs fold change expression analysis based ΔΔCt method using Student's t-test. supports analysis one target genes evaluated two experimental conditions (e.g. control vs treatment).

title: ΔΔCt method t-test analysis — TTEST_DDCt
code: TTEST_DDCt(   x,   numberOfrefGenes,   Factor.level.order = NULL,   paired = FALSE,   var.equal = TRUE,   p.adj = "none",   order = "none",   plotType = "RE" )

title: ΔΔCt method t-test analysis — TTEST_DDCt
text: x data frame containing experimental conditions, biological replicates, amplification efficiency Ct values target reference genes. number biological replicates must equal across genes. true, NA values use ANODA_DDCt function independent samples REPEATED_DDCt paired samples. See package vignette details required data structure. numberOfrefGenes Integer specifying number reference genes used normalization. Factor.level.order Optional character vector specifying order factor levels. NULL, first level factor column used calibrator. paired Logical; TRUE, paired t-test performed. var.equal Logical; TRUE, equal variances assumed pooled variance estimate used. Otherwise, Welch's t-test applied. p.adj Method p-value adjustment. One "holm", "hochberg", "hommel", "bonferroni", "BH", "", "fdr", "none". See p.adjust. order Optional character vector specifying order genes output plot. plotType Plot scale use: "RE" relative expression "log2FC" log2 fold change.

title: ΔΔCt method t-test analysis — TTEST_DDCt
text: list following components: Result Table containing RE values, log2FC, p-values, significance codes,   confidence intervals, standard errors, lower/upper SE limits. RE_Plot Bar plot relative expression values. log2FC_Plot Bar plot log2 fold change values.

title: ΔΔCt method t-test analysis — TTEST_DDCt
text: Relative expression values computed using one reference genes normalization. paired unpaired experimental designs supported. Paired samples quantitative PCR refer measurements collected individuals two different conditions (e.g. vs treatment), whereas unpaired samples originate different individuals condition. Paired designs allow within-individual comparisons typically reduce inter-individual variability. function returns numerical summaries well bar plots based either relative expression (RE) log2 fold change (log2FC).

title: ΔΔCt method t-test analysis — TTEST_DDCt
text: Livak, K. J. Schmittgen, T. D. (2001). Analysis Relative Gene Expression Data Using Real-Time Quantitative PCR Double Delta CT Method. Methods, 25(4), 402–408. doi:10.1006/meth.2001.1262 Ganger, M. T., Dietz, G. D., Ewing, S. J. (2017). common base method analysis qPCR data application simple blocking qPCR experiments. BMC Bioinformatics, 18, 1–11. Yuan, J. S., Reed, ., Chen, F., Stewart, N. (2006). Statistical Analysis Real-Time PCR Data. BMC Bioinformatics, 7, 85.

title: ΔΔCt method t-test analysis — TTEST_DDCt
text: Ghader Mirzaghaderi

title: ΔΔCt method t-test analysis — TTEST_DDCt
code: # Example data structure data1 <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_1factor_one_ref.csv", package = "rtpcr"))  # Unpaired t-test TTEST_DDCt(   data1,   paired = FALSE,   var.equal = TRUE,   numberOfrefGenes = 1) #> *** 3 target(s) using 1 reference gene(s) was analysed! #> *** The control level was used as calibrator. #> $Result #>      Gene     RE    LCL    UCL pvalue     se  log2FC Lower.se.RE Upper.se.RE #> 1 C2H2_26 0.4373 0.1926 0.9927 0.0488 0.4218 -1.1933      0.3264      0.5858 #> 2 C2H2_01 4.0185 2.4598 6.5649 0.0014 0.2193  2.0067      3.4518      4.6783 #> 3 C2H2_12 1.6472 0.9595 2.8279 0.0624 0.2113  0.7200      1.4228      1.9069 #>   sig Lower.se.log2FC Upper.se.log2FC #> 1   *         -1.5985         -0.8908 #> 2  **          1.7237          2.3361 #> 3              0.6219          0.8335 #>  #> $plot  #>   # With amplification efficiencies data2 <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_1factor_one_ref_Eff.csv", package = "rtpcr"))  TTEST_DDCt(   data2,   paired = FALSE,   var.equal = TRUE,   numberOfrefGenes = 1) #> *** 1 target(s) using 1 reference gene(s) was analysed! #> *** The control level was used as calibrator. #> $Result #>     Gene    RE    LCL    UCL pvalue     se  log2FC Lower.se.RE Upper.se.RE sig #> 1 target 0.409 0.2388 0.7006 0.0099 0.1985 -1.2897      0.3565      0.4694  ** #>   Lower.se.log2FC Upper.se.log2FC #> 1           -1.48          -1.124 #>  #> $plot  #>   # Two reference genes data3 <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "data_1factor_Two_ref.csv", package = "rtpcr")) TTEST_DDCt(   data3,   numberOfrefGenes = 2,   var.equal = TRUE,   p.adj = "BH") #> *** 1 target(s) using 2 reference gene(s) was analysed! #> *** The control level was used as calibrator. #> $Result #>   Gene     RE    LCL    UCL pvalue     se  log2FC Lower.se.RE Upper.se.RE sig #> 1 DER5 0.4341 0.1915 0.9839 0.0473 0.4204 -1.2039      0.3244       0.581   * #>   Lower.se.log2FC Upper.se.log2FC #> 1         -1.6111         -0.8996 #>  #> $plot  #>
